   "source": [
    "# Risk, Uncertainty, and Probability Distribution."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "52b2462f",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "Consider a construction manager who oversees a team of workers. The daily workload includes managing tasks for 20 workers per day. Unfortunately, due to absenteeism, about 20% of workers fail to show up for work, leading to project delays and increased costs for the construction company.\n",
    "\n",
    "In this activity, we will walk through the process of finding the ideal number of workers the manager should schedule per day to ensure the project stays on track, assuming only 80% of the scheduled workers show up.\n",
    "\n",
    "Objective:\n",
    "\n",
    "How many workers the construction manager should schedule to ensure that, on average, 20 workers are available each day?"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 1,
   "id": "20701971",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "workers the manager should schedule to ensure that, on average, 20 workers are available each day: 25\n"
     ]
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "import scipy\n",
    "from scipy.stats import binom\n",
    "\n",
    "#Max number of workers per day \n",
    "max_workers = 20\n",
    "#Percentage of workers that show up\n",
    "prob = 0.80\n",
    "\n",
    "x = int(max_workers/ 0.8)\n",
    "print('workers the manager should schedule to ensure that, on average, 20 workers are available each day:' ,x)"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": null,
   "id": "d7bad221",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [],
   "source": []
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "cca55448",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "- The construction manager assumed that 20% of workers don't show up to work ( historical data).\n",
    "- The number of workers scheduled is  20 (fixed).\n",
    "- Each worker (observation) is independent.\n",
    "- Each observation represents one of two outcomes (\"showing up = success\" or \"not shpwing up = failure\").\n",
    "- The probability of \"success\" p is the same for each outcome.\n",
    "\n",
    "we can assume that we have a binomial distribution model.\n",
    "\n",
    "Similarly to how we calculate the normal distribution's Cumulative density function and Probability density function, we do the same for this normal distribution. \n",
    "\n",
    "First fill in the x and probability values to display the normal distribution of the linearly calculated value you found in the previous step.\n"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 6,
   "id": "480de212",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 640x480 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "import scipy\n",
    "from scipy.stats import binom\n",
    "import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n",
    "\n",
    "# set  the values of x and prob\n",
    "x = 25\n",
    "prob = 0.8 # probability of workers showing up.\n",
    "# defining list of r values\n",
    "r_values = list(range(x + 1))\n",
    "\n",
    "# generate the \"dist\" variable by calling the binom.pmf() function below. this will be the list of pmf values\n",
    " \n",
    "dist = scipy.stats.binom.pmf(r_values ,x , prob)\n",
    "# Plotting the graph. Do not change. Used for grading\n",
    "plots = plt.bar(r_values, dist)\n",
    "xy = []\n",
    "for plot in plots:\n",
    "    xy.append(plot.get_xy())\n",
    "plt.show()"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "22e3067d",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "Find the cumulative density function to statistically calculate how many workers (in percent) will the manager schedule  d if we use the linear calculations from the first step to schedule workers."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 7,
   "id": "b065e1d8",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "Probability that at least 20 workers show up: 0.6167\n"
     ]
    },
    {
     "data": {
      "image/png": "",
      "text/plain": [
       "<Figure size 640x480 with 1 Axes>"
      ]
     },
     "metadata": {},
     "output_type": "display_data"
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "import numpy as np\n",
    "import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n",
    "from scipy.stats import binom\n",
    "\n",
    "# Given parameters\n",
    "p = 0.8  # Probability of a worker showing up\n",
    "n = 25  # Number of workers scheduled (from the linear calculation)\n",
    "desired_workers = 20  # Number of workers needed to show up\n",
    "\n",
    "# Calculate the CDF for up to the desired number of workers\n",
    "x = np.arange(0, n + 1)\n",
    "cdf_values = binom.cdf(x, n, p)\n",
    "\n",
    "# Probability that fewer than desired_workers show up\n",
    "prob_fewer_than_desired = binom.cdf(desired_workers - 1, n, p)\n",
    "prob_at_least_desired = 1 - prob_fewer_than_desired\n",
    "\n",
    "print(f\"Probability that at least {desired_workers} workers show up: {prob_at_least_desired:.4f}\")\n",
    "\n",
    "# Plot the CDF\n",
    "plt.plot(x, cdf_values, marker='o')\n",
    "plt.axvline(desired_workers, color='r', linestyle='--')\n",
    "plt.title('Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF) of Workers Showing Up')\n",
    "plt.xlabel('Number of Workers Showing Up')\n",
    "plt.ylabel('Cumulative Probability')\n",
    "plt.grid()\n",
    "plt.show()\n"
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "markdown",
   "id": "b616894e",
   "metadata": {},
   "source": [
    "use the binomial ppf() function to find the number of workers the manager should shedule if he wants to limit the \n",
    "\n",
    "risk of having more than 20 workers per day to 5%."
   ]
  },
  {
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 8,
   "id": "0ea13b2b",
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "name": "stdout",
     "output_type": "stream",
     "text": [
      "The construction manager should schedule 29 workers per day.\n"
     ]
    }
   ],
   "source": [
    "import numpy as np\n",
    "from scipy.stats import binom\n",
    "\n",
    "# Given parameters\n",
    "p = 0.8  # Probability of a worker showing up\n",
    "desired_workers = 20  # Number of workers needed to show up\n",
    "risk_threshold = 0.05  # Risk threshold for having fewer than 20 workers\n",
    "\n",
    "# Calculate the minimum number of workers to schedule to meet the risk threshold\n",
    "# We start with the linear calculation result and adjust upwards if necessary\n",
    "n_start = int(np.ceil(desired_workers / p))\n",
    "found = False\n",
    "for n in range(n_start, n_start + 100):  # 100 is arbitrary, should be sufficiently large\n",
    "    if binom.cdf(desired_workers - 1, n, p) <= risk_threshold:\n",
    "        optimal_workers = n\n",
    "        found = True\n",
    "        break\n",
    "\n",
    "if found:\n",
    "    print(f\"The construction manager should schedule {optimal_workers} workers per day.\")\n",
    "else:\n",
    "    print(\"Unable to find an optimal number of workers with the given parameters.\")\n"
   ]
  },
